courseDescription: 16-week intensive program to become a job-ready full-stack developer

weeks.title: Week 1: HTML & Web Fundamentals
weeks.description: Master the structure of the web and create semantic HTML documents. Learn how the internet works, build accessible websites, and use developer tools effectively.

sections.title: Week 1 Introduction & Overview
sections.description: Welcome to Week 1! This week we focus on HTML - the foundation of all web pages

content.content: Welcome to Week 1! This week, you'll learn HTML - the foundation of every website on the internet. HTML (HyperText Markup Language) defines the structure and content of web pages. By the end of this week, you'll build a complete multi-page personal portfolio website.
Understanding the structure of the web and creating semantic, accessible HTML documents

items: Understand how the internet works (HTTP, DNS, browsers)
Write semantic HTML using appropriate tags
Create forms, tables, and embed media elements
Implement accessibility best practices (ARIA, alt text)
Use browser developer tools to debug HTML
Build a complete multi-page website from scratch

content.content: Personal Portfolio Landing Page (HTML only) - A professional 3-page website with:

items: Contact page with a working form
Valid HTML that passes W3C validation

content.content: Let's get started! üöÄ

sections.title: Lesson 1: How the Internet Works
sections.description: Understanding HTTP, DNS, browsers, and client-server architecture

content.content: Before we dive into writing HTML, it's important to understand how the internet actually works. When you type a URL into your browser, a complex series of events happens in milliseconds to display a web page.

items: Understand what HTTP and HTTPS are
Describe how DNS translates domain names to IP addresses
Explain what happens when you visit a website
Identify the role of web browsers

content.title: How the Internet Works in 5 Minutes (5 min)
How The Web Works - The Big Picture (12 min)
What is HTTP? (15 min)
content.description: Deep dive into HTTP protocol and requests

content.title: DNS Explained in 100 Seconds (2 min)
content.description: Quick explanation of Domain Name System

content.content: Client-Server Model: Your browser (client) requests data from a web server, which sends back HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and other resources.
HTTP (HyperText Transfer Protocol): The protocol browsers use to communicate with web servers. HTTPS is the secure version using encryption.
DNS (Domain Name System): Translates human-readable domain names (like google.com) into IP addresses (like 142.250.80.46) that computers use.
IP Address: A unique numerical identifier for every device connected to the internet (like a street address for your computer).
Web Browser: Software that requests, receives, and displays web pages (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge).

content.text: What Happens When You Visit a Website?

items: Browser asks DNS server: 'What's the IP address for example.com?'
Browser sends HTTP request to that IP address
Server processes the request and sends back HTML, CSS, JS files
Browser receives files and renders the web page

content.content: HTTP uses different 'verbs' for different actions:

items: GET - Request data from a server (viewing a webpage)
POST - Send data to a server (submitting a form)
PUT - Update existing data on a server
DELETE - Remove data from a server

content.content: A URL (Uniform Resource Locator) has several parts:

content.code:
https://www.example.com:443/path/to/page?name=value#section

https://     - Protocol (HTTP Secure)
www          - Subdomain
example.com  - Domain name
:443         - Port (optional, 443 is default for HTTPS)
/path/to/page - Path to resource
?name=value  - Query parameters
#section     - Fragment (anchor to page section)

questions.question: What does DNS stand for?
questions.explanation: DNS (Domain Name System) translates human-readable domain names like google.com into IP addresses that computers use to identify each other.

questions.question: Which HTTP method is used when you submit a form?
questions.explanation: POST is used to send data to a server, such as when submitting a form. GET is for retrieving data, while PUT and DELETE are for updating and removing data.

questions.question: What does the HTTP status code 404 mean?
questions.explanation: 404 means 'Not Found' - the requested resource doesn't exist on the server. This is one of the most common error codes you'll encounter.

questions.question: What is the difference between HTTP and HTTPS?
options: HTTP works on mobile, HTTPS doesn't
questions.explanation: HTTPS (HTTP Secure) encrypts data between your browser and the server, protecting sensitive information like passwords and credit card numbers from being intercepted.

sections.title: Lesson 2: HTML Document Structure and Semantics
sections.description: Learn proper HTML structure and semantic tags for meaningful markup

content.content: HTML (HyperText Markup Language) is the skeleton of every web page. It defines the structure and content using 'tags' that tell browsers how to display information. Semantic HTML means using tags that clearly describe their content's meaning.

content.title: HTML Tutorial for Beginners (1 hour)
content.description: Comprehensive HTML tutorial covering all basics

content.title: Learn HTML in 12 Minutes (12 min)
content.description: Quick overview of essential HTML concepts

content.title: HTML Semantic Elements Explained (18 min)
content.description: Understanding semantic HTML for better structure

content.code:
Main Heading

This is a paragraph.

items: <!DOCTYPE html> - Tells browser this is HTML5
<meta name="viewport"> - Makes site responsive on mobile

items: <main> - Main content of the page (only one per page)

content.content: ‚ùå Non-semantic (bad):

content.code:
...
...

content.content: ‚úÖ Semantic (good):

content.code:
<header>
    <nav>...</nav>
</header>
<main>
    <article>...</article>
</main>

items: Better SEO - Search engines understand content structure
Accessibility - Screen readers navigate content more easily
Maintainability - Code is easier to read and update
Future-proof - Works better with new technologies

questions.question: Which tag contains metadata about the HTML document?
questions.explanation: The <head> element contains metadata about the document including title, character set, styles, and scripts. This content is not displayed on the page.

questions.question: What is the purpose of semantic HTML?
options: To clearly describe the meaning of content
questions.explanation: Semantic HTML uses tags that clearly describe their content's meaning (like <article>, <nav>, <footer>), improving accessibility, SEO, and code maintainability.

questions.question: Which element represents the main content of a page?
questions.explanation: The <main> element represents the dominant content of the page. There should be only one <main> element per page, and it shouldn't be inside <article>, <aside>, <footer>, <header>, or <nav>.

questions.question: What does the alt attribute in an tag do?
options: Provides alternative text for screen readers
questions.explanation: The alt attribute provides alternative text that describes the image. It's displayed if the image fails to load and is read by screen readers for accessibility.

sections.title: Lesson 3: Forms, Tables, and Media Elements
sections.description: Create interactive forms, structured tables, and embed media

content.content: Forms allow users to input data, tables organize information in rows and columns, and media elements embed images, videos, and audio. These are essential components of modern websites.

content.title: HTML Forms Tutorial (25 min)
content.description: Complete guide to creating HTML forms

content.title: HTML Tables in 10 Minutes (10 min)
content.description: Quick guide to creating accessible tables

content.content: Forms collect user input and send it to a server. Here's a complete contact form example:

content.code:
<form action="/submit" method="POST">
    <!-- Text input -->
    <label for="name">Name:</label>
    <input type="text" id="name" name="name" required>
    
    <!-- Email input with validation -->
    <label for="email">Email:</label>
    <input type="email" id="email" name="email" required>
    
    <!-- Password input -->
    <label for="password">Password:</label>
    <input type="password" id="password" name="password" minlength="8">
    
    <!-- Textarea for longer text -->
    <label for="message">Message:</label>
    <textarea id="message" name="message" rows="4"></textarea>
    
    <!-- Radio buttons (select one) -->
    <fieldset>
        <legend>Preferred Contact Method:</legend>
        <input type="radio" id="email-contact" name="contact" value="email">
        <label for="email-contact">Email</label>
        
        <input type="radio" id="phone-contact" name="contact" value="phone">
        <label for="phone-contact">Phone</label>
    </fieldset>
    
    <!-- Checkboxes (select multiple) -->
    <label>
        <input type="checkbox" name="subscribe" value="yes">
        Subscribe to newsletter
    </label>
    
    <!-- Dropdown select -->
    <label for="country">Country:</label>
    <select id="country" name="country">
        <option value="">-- Select --</option>
        <option value="us">United States</option>
        <option value="uk">United Kingdom</option>
        <option value="ca">Canada</option>
    </select>
    
    <!-- File upload -->
    <label for="file">Upload Resume:</label>
    <input type="file" id="file" name="resume" accept=".pdf,.doc,.docx">
    
    <!-- Submit button -->
    <button type="submit">Send Message</button>
</form>

items: readonly - Field can be seen but not edited

content.content: Tables organize data in rows and columns:

content.code:
Student Grades
Name Subject Grade
Alice Johnson Mathematics 95
Bob Smith Science 88
Carol Davis History 92
Average 91.7

<video width="640" height="360" controls>
    <source src="video.mp4" type="video/mp4">
    <source src="video.webm" type="video/webm">
    Your browser doesn't support video.
</video>

<!-- YouTube embed -->
<iframe width="560" height="315" 
    src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/dQw4w9WgXcQ"
    title="Video title"
    frameborder="0"
    allowfullscreen>
</iframe>

<audio controls>
    <source src="audio.mp3" type="audio/mpeg">
    <source src="audio.ogg" type="audio/ogg">
    Your browser doesn't support audio.
</audio>

items: Create a contact form with name, email, message fields
Add a table showing your favorite books or movies
Embed an image with proper alt text
Add a YouTube video using iframe
Test your form inputs with different values

sections.title: Lesson 4: Accessibility Best Practices
sections.description: Make your websites accessible to everyone with ARIA and semantic HTML

content.content: Web accessibility means making websites usable by everyone, including people with disabilities. This includes those using screen readers, keyboard navigation, or other assistive technologies. Accessible websites are also better for SEO and mobile users.

content.title: ARIA Labels and Roles Explained (12 min)
Keyboard Navigation in Web Apps (10 min)
content.description: Making sites navigable without a mouse

items: 15% of the world has some form of disability
It's the law in many countries (ADA in US, WCAG internationally)
It's the right thing to do

content.content: Using semantic HTML is the foundation of accessibility:

content.code:
• Home
  • About
Home About

content.content: Always provide descriptive alt text:
Every form input needs a label:

content.code:
<!-- ‚úÖ GOOD: Label associated with input -->
<label for="email">Email Address:</label>
<input type="email" id="email" name="email">

<!-- ‚ùå BAD: No label -->
<input type="email" placeholder="Email">

<!-- Alternative: Wrap input in label -->
<label>
    Email:
    <input type="email" name="email">
</label>

content.content: ARIA attributes provide additional context for assistive technologies:

content.code:
Confirm Action

Are you sure?

Password must be at least 8 characters

Form submitted successfully!

content.content: Ensure all interactive elements work with keyboard:

content.code:
Click me
Skip to main content

content.content: Ensure sufficient color contrast for readability:

items: WCAG AA: Minimum contrast ratio of 4.5:1 for normal text
WCAG AAA: Enhanced contrast ratio of 7:1
Don't rely on color alone to convey information
Test with tools like WebAIM Contrast Checker

content.code:
Student Enrollment by Department
Department Students
Computer Science 150
Mathematics 120

items: Test keyboard navigation (Tab, Enter, Arrow keys)
Use a screen reader (NVDA, JAWS, VoiceOver)
Check color contrast with online tools
Validate HTML (invalid HTML breaks screen readers)
Use automated tools like axe DevTools or WAVE
‚úì Forms have labels for all inputs
‚úì Color contrast meets WCAG AA standards
‚úì Page has proper heading hierarchy (h1, h2, h3)
‚úì Skip to main content link present

questions.question: What is the purpose of the alt attribute in images?
options: To provide alternative text for screen readers and when images don't load
To add a tooltip when hovering
questions.explanation: The alt attribute provides alternative text that describes the image. It's read by screen readers for visually impaired users and displayed if the image fails to load.

questions.question: What does ARIA stand for?
questions.explanation: ARIA (Accessible Rich Internet Applications) is a set of attributes that make web content and applications more accessible to people with disabilities.

questions.question: Which is the correct way to label a form input for accessibility?
questions.explanation: Using <label for="id"> explicitly associates the label with the input using the id attribute. This helps screen readers and improves usability by making the entire label clickable.

questions.question: What is the minimum color contrast ratio for normal text according to WCAG AA?
questions.explanation: WCAG AA requires a minimum contrast ratio of 4.5:1 for normal-sized text. This ensures text is readable for users with visual impairments or color blindness.

sections.title: Lesson 5: Developer Tools and Debugging HTML
sections.description: Master browser DevTools to inspect, debug, and optimize your HTML

content.content: Browser Developer Tools (DevTools) are essential for web development. They let you inspect HTML, modify styles in real-time, debug JavaScript, monitor network requests, and much more. Every professional developer uses DevTools daily.

content.title: Chrome DevTools Crash Course (30 min)
content.description: Comprehensive guide to using Chrome DevTools

content.title: HTML Debugging Tips and Tricks (12 min)
content.description: Common HTML errors and how to fix them

content.title: Inspect Element Like a Pro (15 min)

items: Chrome menu ‚Üí More Tools ‚Üí Developer Tools

content.content: The Elements panel lets you inspect and modify HTML/CSS:

items: Edit HTML in real-time (changes are temporary)
See computed styles for any element
Test CSS changes before editing your code
View box model (margin, border, padding, content)

content.content: How to inspect specific elements:

items: Click the 'Select Element' icon (top-left of DevTools)
Hover over page elements to highlight them
Click to select and view in Elements panel

content.content: The Console displays errors, warnings, and log messages:
Monitor all network requests:

items: See all files loaded (HTML, CSS, JS, images)
Check file sizes and load times
Throttle network speed to test on slow connections
Filter by file type or search

sections.title: Assignment 1: Personal Portfolio Landing Page
sections.description: Build a professional multi-page HTML website - Due Week 2, Wednesday 11:59 PM

content.content: Create a professional, multi-page personal portfolio website using only HTML (no CSS yet!). This project demonstrates your understanding of semantic HTML, forms, tables, accessibility, and proper document structure.

content.title: Personal Portfolio Landing Page (HTML Only)
content.description: Build a complete 3-page portfolio website showcasing yourself as a developer. Focus on semantic HTML structure, accessibility, and clean code. You'll receive peer reviews from 2 classmates and review 2 others' work.

rubric.description: Proper use of header, nav, main, section, article, footer elements
Clean, well-indented code with proper comments
Alt text, labels, ARIA attributes, semantic markup
All required pages and sections included
Proper use of semantic HTML5 elements (header, nav, main, section, article, footer)
Complete about section with bio, image, skills list
At least 3 projects with descriptions, images, and links
Working form with proper labels, validation, and accessibility
Alt text, labels, ARIA where needed, keyboard navigation
All pages pass W3C HTML validation with no errors

content.content: Must include:

items: Header with your name and navigation menu
Main section with your photo (with alt text!)
About section with 2-3 paragraphs about yourself
Education/experience section (use table or ordered list)
Footer with copyright and social links
Navigation links to all three pages

content.content: Must include:

items: Same header and navigation as home page
At least 3 project showcases using <article> or <section>
Each project needs: title, description, image, GitHub link

content.content: Must include:

items: Same header and navigation as other pages
All inputs must have proper <label> elements
‚úÖ All images have descriptive alt text
‚úÖ At least one table with proper headers
‚úÖ At least one list (ul or ol)

items: Are semantic HTML elements used properly?
Do all images have alt text?
Does the code look clean and organized?
Are there any obvious HTML errors?
Give at least 2 specific positive comments
Start early! Don't wait until the last day
Validate your HTML frequently, not just at the end
Use semantic elements instead of generic divs
Test your navigation - make sure all links work
Write descriptive alt text for all images
Keep your code organized and well-indented
Add comments to explain your structure
Test on different browsers if possible
üîç Check example portfolios in resources folder

content.content: Good luck! This portfolio will be the foundation for your online presence as a developer. Make it count! üöÄ

sections.title: Week 1 Final Assessment
sections.description: Test your HTML knowledge with this comprehensive quiz

content.content: Test your understanding of HTML and web fundamentals. This quiz covers everything from Week 1. You have 45 minutes and 2 attempts.

questions.question: What does HTML stand for?
questions.explanation: HTML stands for HyperText Markup Language. It's the standard markup language for creating web pages.

questions.question: Which tag is used for the most important heading?
questions.explanation: <h1> is used for the most important heading. There should typically be only one <h1> per page for proper semantic structure.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the <nav> element?
questions.explanation: The <nav> element represents a section of navigation links. It's a semantic element that helps structure your page and improves accessibility.

questions.question: Which attribute makes a form input required?
questions.explanation: The 'required' attribute makes a form field mandatory. The browser will prevent form submission if required fields are empty.

questions.question: What does the viewport meta tag do?
options: Makes the site responsive on mobile devices
questions.explanation: The viewport meta tag controls how your site displays on mobile devices. It tells the browser to scale the page to fit the device width.

questions.question: Which element represents self-contained content like a blog post?
questions.explanation: The <article> element represents self-contained, independently distributable content like a blog post, news article, or forum post.

questions.question: How do you create an email input field?
questions.explanation: <input type="email"> creates an email input field with built-in validation. The browser will check if the input is a valid email format.

questions.question: What's the correct way to link to another page?
questions.explanation: Link is the correct syntax. The 'href' attribute specifies the URL of the page the link goes to.

questions.question: Which tag defines table data?
questions.explanation: <td> (table data) defines a standard cell in a table. <th> is for header cells.

questions.question: What does WCAG stand for?
questions.explanation: WCAG stands for Web Content Accessibility Guidelines. They provide standards for making web content more accessible to people with disabilities.

content.content: Congratulations on completing Week 1! You now have a solid foundation in HTML and web fundamentals. Next week, we'll make your websites beautiful with CSS! üé®
